subsections.name: Delaware Precincts
subsections.content:
The Delaware election district (precinct) shapefile was obtained from Delaware FirstMap Data, a GIS service of the State of Delaware. Election data come from the Delaware Department of Elections. 2010 Decennial Census demographic data were downloaded from the Census API. The 2010 census block shapefile for Delaware was downloaded from the US Census Bureau’s TIGER/Line Shapefiles.

Some very limited merging of precincts in the tabular election data was necessary to join to the precinct shapefile. Data from three countywide precincts that reported absentee votes were disaggregated by voting age population using MGGG’s proration software. Demographic data was aggregated from the block level using MGGG’s proration software. State legislative district IDs were also assigned to precincts using this package.

subsections.name: Florida Census blocks and block groups
subsections.content:
Where you will find blocks: City of Miami map.

Where you will find block groups: Miami-Dade County map.

These data were obtained from the US Census Bureau. The shapefile for Miami-Dade county was downloaded from the Census's TIGER/Line Shapefiles. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from the Census API. At the block group level, 2018 population estimates, household income, and homeownership data were obtained from the ACS.

subsections.name: Georgia Precincts
subsections.content: These data for this module were obtained from the Georgia General Assembly Legislative and Congressional Reapportionment Office, the MIT Elections Data and Science Lab (MEDSL), and National Historic GIS (NHGIS). The precinct shapefile for Georgia was downloaded from the Georgia General Assembly Legislative and Congressional Reapportionment Office's website and 2016 election results were downloaded from the MEDSL. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from NHGIS. The source shapefile for this module, along with additional information about processing, is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.

subsections.name: Hawaii Precints
subsections.content:
This shapefile comes from Hawaii Statewide GIS Program and was processed by Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering Group (MGGG) staff.

This precinct shapefile comes from the Hawaii Statewide GIS Program in the State Office of Planning. Election results come from the State of Hawaii Office of Elections. 2010 Decennial Census demographic data were downloaded from the Census API. The 2010 census block shapefile for Hawaii was downloaded from the US Census Bureau’s TIGER/Line Shapefiles.

Precincts 41-02 and 41-05 were merged as were precincts 42-01 and 42-04 in order to join 2016 and 2018 results onto the same precinct boundaries. Demographic data were aggregated from the block level using MGGG’s proration software.

Concentrated poverty
≥ 25% of households under $20K annual income
Concentrated wealth
≥ 25% of households over $150K annual income
Segregated
only one racial group exceeds 1/4 of population
Hypersegregated
only one racial group exceeds 1/6 of population
Highly diverse
three racial groups exceed 1/4 of population

plans.title: 50 single-member wards built out of precincts
10 multi-member wards built out of precincts
10 multi-member wards built out of community areas

subsections.name: City Council Districts in Chicago
subsections.content:
The City of Chicago is divided into 50 districts, known as wards, for the City Council. The Chicago City Council is represented by 50 elected officials, known as aldermen. Each alderman is elected by and represents a single ward.

The current ward plan in Chicago is widely criticized for being gerrymandered. Some argue that the 50-member city council is inefficiently large. Today, the demographic makeup of Chicago is split roughly in thirds between Hispanic, Black, and White racial/ethnic groups. Black populations are the most densely clustered in the city, but the Black percentage as a total share of the population has been decreasing in recent decades. Due to the high levels of segregation in the city, the current wards tend to be dominated by one racial/ethnic group with an alderman nearly always coming from that dominant group. Latinos are the most underrepresented group, with only 22% representation in the city council despite making up 29% of the population.

subsections.name: Research
subsections.content:
These maps were created as part of MGGG's Study of Reform Proposals for Chicago City Council. We set out to explore how different districts, or moving to multi-member districts, might impact representation and better promote a fair and responsive city government. The report considered the following reform methods:

  • Redrawing the lines in the current 50-ward system
  • Shrinking the city council from 50 members to 30 or fewer
  • Moving from single-member districts to multi-member districts
  • Moving from plurality elections to ranked choice voting

You can read more background and access the report here.

subsections.name: Chicago Community Areas and Precincts
subsections.content: In the 1920s, researchers at the University of Chicago divided the city into 77 community areas that have played an important role in city planning and culture since their inception and serve as proxies for neighborhoods. The community area and precinct shapefiles were downloaded from the Chicago Data Portal. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from American FactFinder. The source shapefiles with demographic information are available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization.

subsections.name: Iowa Counties
subsections.content: Iowa has strict laws requiring that congressional districts be built out of counties. The county shapefile comes from the US Census Bureau's TIGER/Line Shapefiles. 2010 Decennial Census demographic data were downloaded from American FactFinder. County level election data for presidential elections since 2000 were obtained from the MIT Elections Data and Science Lab. The source shapefile for this module, along with additional informationabout processing, is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.

subsections.name: Maine Precints
subsections.content: The Maine precinct shapefile was obtained from the Maine Geolibrary and processed by members of the Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering Group (MGGG). Election data come from the Maine Bureau of Corporations, Elections, & Commissions. Data from absentee votes reported at the state level were disaggregated by voting age population. Because of data reporting and processing, a few precincts cross county boundaries. Demographic data for the 2010 Decennial Census were retrieved using the Census API. More information about our data sources and processing can be found here.

subsections.name: Maryland Precints
subsections.content: The Maryland precinct shapefile was obtained from the Maryland Department of Planning's Redistricting website and processed by members of the Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering Group (MGGG). Election data come from the Maryland State Board of Elections. It is important to note that Maryland only releases election day ballots cast at the precinct level and the election results here do not include early, absentee or provisional votes. More information about our data sources and processing can be found here.

Each of the Lowell plans was generated by randomized algorithms, while making sure that the Asian and Latino communities meet the statistical thresholds laid out in the legal requirements, where applicable.

plans.title: Lowell | Sample valid 8-district plans (Option on the Ballot)

subsections.name: Research
subsections.content: The statewide amps were created to aid in a paper, "Locating the representational baseline: Republicans in Massachusetts," written by MGGG and collaborators. Despite Republicans usually gaining between 30% and 40% of the two-way vote share in statewide elections, Massachusetts has not elected a Republican to the US House of Representatives since 1994. The paper finds that the underperformance of Republicans in Massachusetts is not the result of gerrymandering or candidate availability, but rather is a factor of the spatial distribution of Republican voters in the state.

subsections.name: Election reform in Lowell
subsections.content:
In 2019, all eyes are on Lowell, Massachusetts. The City of Lowell’s at-large electoral system has been challenged in a recent lawsuit (Huot et al. v. City of Lowell et al). Plaintiffs in the case argued that the current system dilutes the votes of Lowell's communities of color for the City Council and School Board. For more information about the lawsuit, read LCR's explainer [here].

This November, Lowell residents will have a chance to vote on a new system! The choices for City Council are (a) a city-wide system electing 9 council members by ranked choice, or (b) 8 districts plus 3 at-large seats, raising the size of the council to 11 members.

Read our public report on the choice facing Lowell voters this November! We explain the options on the ballot and some general differences between systems of election. For more technical explanations of our modeling, refer to our detailed report.

Versions of the public report are also available in Spanish, Portuguese, and Cambodian Khmer.

subsections.name: Massachusetts Precincts
subsections.content:
Where you will find precincts: Statewide maps.

There are two vintages of precincts in these maps, one from the 2000 redistricting cycle and another from the 2010 redistricting cycle. The 2002-2010 raw, unprocessed shapefile comes from the United States Census Bureau and was sent to MGGG by Secretary of the Commonwealth Francis Galvin's office. The 2012-2016 raw, unprocessed precinct shapefile comes from the office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, William Francis Galvin. All election data comes from the Secretary of the Commonwealth's Elections Division website. The source precinct shapefiles, along with additional information about processing, are available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.

subsections.name: Massachusetts Towns and Municipalities

Where you will find towns: Statewide maps

The town shapefile was downloaded from the Massachusetts Bureau of Geographic Information website.

Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from American FactFinder. The source shapefile with demographic information is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @gerrymandr.

subsections.name: Research
subsections.content: This Mississippi module comes out of a project from MGGG's Voting Rights Data Institute that explored how many majority-Black congressional districts are possible to draw. A write-up of this experiment is forthcoming.

subsections.name: Mississippi block groups
subsections.content: These data were obtained from the US Census Bureau. The block group shapefile for Mississippi was downloaded from the Census's TIGER/Line Shapefiles. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from American FactFinder. The source shapefile with demographic information is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @gerrymandr.

sections.name: About the data
sections.content: The units used here are census blocks. Data for this module were obtained from the US Census Bureau. The block shapefile for Nevada was downloaded from the Census's TIGER/Line Shapefiles. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from the Census API.

subsections.name: New Mexico Precincts
subsections.content: The New Mexico precinct shapefile was obtained from the New Mexico Resource Geographic Information System (RGIS), which is managed by the Earth Data Analysis Center (EDAC) at the University of New Mexico. It was processed by members of the Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering Group (MGGG). The Congressional, State Senate and State House district map shape files, as well as the 2010 census block shape file are from the US Census Bureau's TIGER/Line Program. Precint level elections returns were provided by the New Mexico Secretary of State's website. Block level demographic data is from the Census API. Statewide election returns from 2016 and 2018 - from the New Mexico Secretary of State - were cleaned by MGGG staff in order to join it with the New Mexico precinct shapefile. Census block data was aggregated to the precinct level using MGGG's proration software.

These data were obtained from the US Census Bureau. The block shapefile for New York was downloaded from the Census's TIGER/Line Shapefiles. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from the Census API.

subsections.name: Rucho v. Common Cause
subsections.content: In March 2019 the US Supreme Court heard oral arguments for Rucho v. Common Cause, in which plaintiffs claim that North Carolina's remedial 2016 congressional map is an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander. The 2016 remedial map had been drawn after the Supreme Court struck down two of the state's 2011 enacted congressional districts as unconstitutional racial gerrymanders. MGGG and our collaborators filed an amicus brief which can be accessed on our website.

subsections.name: North Carolina voting tabulation districts (VTDs)
subsections.content: These data were obtained from the North Carolina General Assembly and National Historic GIS (NHGIS). The VTD shapefile and election results were downloaded from the North Carolina General Assembly's 2016 Redistricting Reference Data. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from NHGIS. The source shapefile for this module, along with additional information about processing, is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.

subsections.name: Ohio Precincts
subsections.content:
This shapefile was compiled and processed by members of the Voting Rights Data Institute (VRDI) and the Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering Group (MGGG). VRDI was a 2018 summer intensive sponsored by MGGG at Tufts and MIT, with major support from a Bose Research Grant at MIT and from the Jonathon M. Tisch College of Civic Life at Tufts.

Raw data for Ohio's precinct boundaries was sourced from election and other county officials and processed by members of MGGG and students at VRDI. For more information on the sourcing of this data, please refer to the Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering Group's Ohio Precincts Github repository. Election data come the Ohio Secretary of State and the MIT Election Data Science Lab. Demographic data were downloaded at the census block level from IPUMS NHGIS.

Demographic data were aggregated from the block level using MGGG’s proration software maup. Congressional, house, and senate district IDs were assigned to precincts also using this package.

subsections.name: Oklahoma Precincts
subsections.content:
This shapefile comes from the University of Oklahoma's Center for Spatial Analysis and processed by members of the Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering Group (MGGG).

This precinct shapefile was obtained from the Oklahoma Data Warehouse hosted by the Center for Spatial Analysis at the University of Oklahoma. Election results come from the Oklahoma State Election Board. 2010 Decennial Census demographic data were downloaded from the Census API. The 2010 census block shapefile as well as congressional and state legislative districts for Oklahoma were downloaded from the US Census Bureau’s TIGER/Line Shapefiles.

Oklahoma reports absentee and early votes at the precinct level for every county except for Oklahoma County and Tulsa County, where non-election day votes are reported for the whole county. For those two counties, absentee and early votes were disaggregated to the precinct level by population. Demographic data were aggregated from the block level and precincts were assigned to congressional and state legislative districts using MGGG’s proration software. Precincts for Pushmataha County were digitized to conform to a map provided by the county.

subsections.name: Redistricting in the court
subsections.content: In February 2018, Moon Duchin was asked by Governor Tom Wolf to provide guidance in evaluating redistricting plans for fairness after the Pennsylvania Supreme Court struck down the 2011 enacted plan as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander. Her report is hosted on MGGG's website.

subsections.name: Pennsylvania voting tabulation districts (VTDs)
subsections.content:
Where you will find precincts: Statewide maps

The raw, unprocessed VTDs were collected from the Census TIGER/Line Shapefiles. Election data was compiled at the precinct level by a private individual and was found to be within 1% of the official state-reported results at the county and state levels. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from American FactFinder. The source shapefile for this module, along with additional information about processing, is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.

subsections.name: Vermont Towns
subsections.content: These data were obtained from the Vermont Open Geodata Portal, the Vermont Secretary of State, and the US Census Bureau. The town shapefile was downloaded from the Vermont Open Geodata Portal and election results were downloaded from the Secretary of State's website. Vermont does not release election results for towns with a total population under 50, thus 9 towns have been excluded from this module. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the sub-county level from American FactFinder. The source shapefile for this module, along with additional information about processing, is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.

subsections.name: Research
subsections.content: In June 2018, the Eastern District Court of Virginia ruled 11 of the House of Delegates districts unconstitutional racial gerrymanders. MGGG published a report evaluating the 2011 Enacted House of Delegates plan as well as several of the proposed alternatives. In April 2019, MGGG published a subsequent report, assessing the potential impacts of a proposed constitutional amendment for redistricting in Virginia, particularly the proposed rules for constraints and priorities in drawing districts.

subsections.name: Reform efforts
subsections.content: In November 2020, voters in Virginia will determine if the power to draw congressional and state legislative districts should be delegated from the General Assembly to a new bipartisan commission of eight state legislators and eight citizens. If voters support this ballot measure, the Virginia Constitution will be amended.

subsections.name: Legal Challenges
subsections.content:
Personhuballah v. Alcorn

This case was filed in 2013 to challenge Virginia’s Third Congressional District as a racial gerrymander. In 2014, a district court ruled in favor of the plaintiff, determining that the district was an unconstitutional racial gerrymander. When this decision was appealed to a higher court, the U.S. Supreme Court vacated and remanded the case back to the district court for reconsideration in 2015. The district court ruled, again, in favor of the plaintiff. After the U.S. Supreme Court found that the case lacked standing to appeal, an outside expert was commissioned to redraw the districts to remedy the gerrymander. A new remedial plan was implemented in 2016.

Vesilind v. Va. State Board of Elections

This case was filed in 2015 to challenge state General Assembly districts for violating Virginia’s constitutional requirement to draw compact districts. The district court ruled that the districts were constitutionally valid in 2017. When this decision was appealed, the Virginia Supreme Court upheld this ruling.

Bethune-Hill v. Virginia Board of Elections

This case was filed in 2014 to challenge 12 State House districts as racial gerrymanders. In 2015, a district court ruled that race did not predominate in 11 of the 12 districts, but race was considered when drawing one district (District 75). However, the court determined that considering race in District 75 was not unconstitutional because the parameter used, a 55% Black voting age population, was justified by the VRA due to highly racially polarized voting in the area of concern. When this decision was appealed to a higher court, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the rationale for District 75 but vacated and remanded the case back to the lower court for the remaining 11 districts. In 2018, the district court amended their ruling, determining that the remaining 11 districts were racial gerrymanders, initiating a redistricting process. In early 2019, a new map was approved. The Virginia House of Delegates appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court (Virginia House of Delegates v. Bethune-Hill), but the court found that the state House lacked standing to appeal.

subsections.name: Virginia Precincts
subsections.content: These data were obtained from the Princeton Gerrymandering Project and National Historic GIS (NHGIS). The precinct shapefile was compiled and joined to election results by the Princeton Gerrymandering Project. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from NHGIS. The source shapefile for this module, along with additional information about processing, is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.

subsections.name: The electoral system in Yakima County
subsections.content:
On January 15, 2020, OneAmerica and Campaign Legal Center (CLC) filed a challenge letter over the current system employed by Yakima County. In it, they argue that the system dilutes the votes of Latinos in Yakima County and is in violation of the Washington Voting Rights Act (WVRA) and the Washington State Constitution. Read the full letter [here].

At first glance, Yakima county seems to already be districted to facilitate minority opportunity to elect candidates of choice. There are three districts; District 1 is mostly White, but District 2 has a slight POC majority, including about 40% Hispanic VAP and an additional 8% Native VAP, while District 3 is 55% Hispanic by VAP.

This is undercut by an unusual—and very problematic—system of electing County Commissioners. Each district is represented by a Commissioner. The primary election is conducted by a district-wide "jungle primary," in which any number of candidates may run and the top two vote-getters advance to the general election without regard to party affiliation. (In fact, candidates with the "prefers Republican" label predominate over all others in Yakima, and this is even true for Hispanic candidates.) But the entire county, and not just the district, then votes to choose a winner between the two finalists. This indicates that the system itself negates any advantage of districting, nullifying the minorities' opportunity to elect.

Read more about our study of Voting Rights in Yakima and possible remedies in our report. Our data is available on our github.

subsections.name: Redistricting in the court | Gill v. Whitford
subsections.content: In June 2018, the US Supreme Court remanded back to the lower courts Gill v. Whitford, a case challenging Wisconsin's state assembly districts as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander.

subsections.name: Wisconsin Wards
subsections.content: Wards are Wisconsin's precinct equivalents. All election data for this module were obtained from the Wisconsin State Legislature. The source shapefile for this module, along with additional information about processing, is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.
